title: CTRL0000928883 - Transcribed Interview of Russel "Rusty" Bowers, (June 19, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 4:33 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
GENERAL COUNSEL TO THE ARIZONA HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
This is a transcribed interview of Russell Bowers
conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the
United States Capitol, pursuant to House Resolution 503.
Mr. Bowers, could you please state your full name and spell your last name for the
My name is Russell Wesley Bowers.
And, Counsel, could you please identify yourself and
spell your last name for the record as well.
I'm Andrew Pappas, general counsel to the Arizona House of
And my last name is P-a-p-p-a-s.
I'm senior investigative counsel for the select
be a staff-led interview, and members, of course, may choose to also ask questions.
In the room today with me is Investigative Counsel
Because this is a virtual interview, if members join, they will likely do so via Webex
and will turn on their cameras if they have any questions.
I'll try to announce their presence when they join so you know who is on.
see right now we have Mr. Schiff has joined us, and if other members join from time to
time, I'll try and note their presence.
There is an official reporter transcribing the record of this interview.
until each question is completed before you begin your response, and we'll try to wait
until your response is complete before we ask our next question.
The stenographer cannot record nonverbal responses such as shaking your head,
so it's important that you answer each question with an audible, verbal response.
We ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
the question's not clear, please ask for clarification.
If you don't know the answer, then
I'm going to offer an admonition here that we make with all witnesses, so please
don't read anything into the fact that I need to remind you that it's unlawful to
deliberately provide false information to Congress and doing so could be a violation of
title 18, United States Code, section 1001, or other statutes.
Mr. Bowers, do you have any questions about anything that I've gone over thus
If at any point during this interview you need to take a break, please
just let us know and you can certainly do so.
How long have you held that position?
I was elected on, let's see, the day after the election -- general election in
Mr. Bowers, are you currently the speaker of the Arizona House of
So whether that was the 3rd or the 4th of
Speaker Bowers, I'd like to begin by giving some context of
You were a strong supporter of President Trump
Were you disappointed that he didn't prevail?
Prior to the election, Speaker Bowers, President Trump was claiming that the
results would be rigged because of alleged fraud related to mail-in voting.
those false claims about rigged elections were productive?
In Arizona, we've been using mail-in balloting and a preliminary vote count
I've known Helen Purcell, the previous recorder, previous to
So I've known her and her professional credentials and had
every confidence that, while there are always things that we could improve, that our vote
by mail and our early balloting would be done professionally and correctly.
In fact, I'm thinking at least 20 years, if not 30.
And, Speaker Bowers, in your view, did President Trump's warnings about
fraud come to pass on election day in Arizona?
In those first days after the election, did you begin to hear various theories
Lots of different stories, anecdotes, many of which are in some
of the things that we've sent in, but people who were denied their witness prerogatives
to witness counting in counting centers, a person who went on to some length about
having a contact with video and/or still photographs of a Korean Airlines jet that brought
a pallet of ballots that were off-loaded and taken to the counting center, things like that,
Sharpiegate, use of sharpies, is that one of the issues --
Sharpies were part of it that was allowed, encouraged, and then
denied, and there was some -- you know, the sharpiegate portion of the discussion of the
conspiracies, and so that was one of many.
Did you see any credible evidence to support any of the conspiracy claims or
claims of election fraud that came up in the days following the election?
I did not see them personally, but I was willing to, at least, ask and to take
those to people that I trusted, our county recorders and other officials who were over the
counting and review them with them.
We will probably talk about later when decisions were taken by the Senate to go a
different way, but I had -- I have a method that I apply to problems, and one is to bring all
the expertise I can to any particular problem before we formulate any plan or resolution,
just to try to learn as much of the lay of the land on anything.
pressing the almost unhinged, extremely uncivil response that was our counting, the large
county counting center, and I just knew I wasn't going to do that, and I needed to
maintain contacts inside who had credible and professional knowledge that I could talk
So a lot of these things, you know, they cause you some questioning, but I have a
And did the people who you asked to look into those various allegations
respond to you or give you information as to what they were finding?
When we did initially begin those discussions, I just said:
Can you help me address those?
And Mr. Pappas was with me at the time that we went to the counting center, but
that was not immediately after the election.
about -- that I should call us into session, that I should throw out the election.
email volume from what I was able to read, we received tens of thousands of emails daily
per my -- I have two assistants, and they were consistently, just all day long, either filing
For a while, much of the discussion was
And so much of -- much of the email subject matter concerned various conspiracy
elements, the machinery, the box, the connections in Bulgaria and Venezuela, and
offshore and the internet possibilities of infringement or -- you've probably heard every
one of these from every other State by now, but a lot of that was the volume, just
In the 17 months since the 2020 election, have you seen or has evidence
been brought to your attention to support any of those conspiracy theories or election
fraud claims that you've just referenced?
There's only one claim that I think had merit and that I knew about
personally, and that was when a Federal judge extended the duration period that we had
established in State law into the voting period.
had cause, but we do not allow registration and voting on the same day, and so there
wheelhouse, not to an extent that was ever brought by any number that would
effectually negate the gap in votes between Mr. Trump and Mr. Biden.
And we also had -- we and other States
And I think that did infringe on a manner that is in our
So, other than that issue regarding the extension of the registration period,
did you ever come across evidence to support any of the other claims of election fraud or
the conspiracy theories that you referenced earlier?
And has any of that evidence been brought to your attention or pointed out
to you by anyone to whom you delegated the task of looking into the claims?
I mean, we would -- Mr. Finchem, one of my
colleagues, made consistent claims and was kind of a broker.
the election that that was sufficient rationale for us to call a committee hearing, give him
the opportunity to hear those claims in an official capacity and et cetera.
And we'd classify these as this ongoing and persistent data about
So counting center fraud, computer fraud in the counting center, witnesses who
said they saw abuse of the processes that had been set up, et cetera, those kind of things
were brought to my attention, and I believe some of those we provided assignment
sheets coming out of counting centers, which meant nothing, but -- but they were at least
brought to my attention and I -- I saw nothing credible.
It was mostly internet-style claims with very little, if any -- in fact, I never saw any
credible evidence, which was part of the challenges that were brought against me by my
enemies, and I will just say it that way.
And they use that that I -- I would say in like in our news release that without any
Well, there's all kinds of evidence.
And I'd say that's -- I mean, I used anecdotes in my mind as what evidence is.
There's credible evidence, and then there's evidence, and there's hearsay
There's types of evidence, but to the level that would
be required in my mind to convince me that there was -- there was sufficient fraud and
sufficient activity that would merit our involvement, no, never found any.
So it sounds like there were a multitude of claims brought to your attention
by constituents, other members of the House of Representatives, but in your view, there
was no credible evidence to support any of those claims.
Speaker Bowers, I understand that, in late November, or November 22nd to
be specific, you received a phone call from President Trump and Rudy Giuliani in which
they discussed the result of the Presidential election in Arizona with you.
Can you describe that phone call for us?
My wife and I returned from church.
We had been in very serious
discussion, President Fann and I, for some -- couple weeks, at least, on what we might do
that would help restore confidence generally and defray some of this activity.
So we had spoken a lot and when our chief first had called and had asked if I had
received -- been in contact with the White House and I said:
Well, they've been trying to get in touch with me, and I don't know
that they're going to ask, but we at least should be on the same page and have some, you
know, not move, take any motion or make any commitment without talking to each
And immediately, on my Bluetooth in my car, it said that the White House was
Well, if you get it, call me back.
And I took that call, and the White House operator asked if I would hold for the
President, and it was Rudy Giuliani who came on and said salutation.
the President would be with us shortly, and shortly thereafter, the President came on.
Speaker Bowers, can I interrupt you for one second?
Is that Karen Fann, the President of the Arizona Senate?
So Mr. Giuliani told you that the President would be coming on the
And he shortly did, shortly thereafter he did.
Collegial, you know, some small talk.
And, again, in the context -- I support the President, and they said:
given to understand -- and I am reconstructing a lot of things in my mind, that is, to my
best memory -- I understand that there are -- there has been a lot of fraud in your
And then he proceeded to give classifications, groups of people, a large amount,
60,000 illegal aliens, you know, large numbers, voted in your election, a number of dead
people voted in your election, fraudulent military ballots were counted in your election,
people that voted and moved -- and he had more.
you have -- do you have proof of that?
I can't remember all of them
Rudy, you -- Mr. Mayor at first, and then it just got down to Rudy -- do
Can you give those to me?
And the President -- and I said:
and I need it on my desk.
I need more than just numbers.
I don't want it -- it's not a thing about a hunch, I think, maybe,
It has to be proof, names, how they voted, on my desk.
Speaker Bowers, can I interrupt you for one moment?
So was the person who started ticking off these claims that there were
60,000 illegal aliens who voted, a number of dead people voted, was that President
Did the President share any of his thoughts or give any input on the specifics
of the claims of election fraud?
He did not, to my recollection.
He did say, because I -- I was insistent that I had to have proof, real proof,
That's the kind of proof I'm talking about.
Rudy, give the man what he wants.
And then he continued in his discussion.
What do you need from the
And then he said -- of the two issues that I remember most, the first was that he
wanted to have a committee meeting.
committee and then be able, I would presume, when you say "official committee," I'm
not talking about an interim ad hoc committee, but an official committee of using one of
our standard standing committees to do it.
He wanted the legislature to hold an official
We'd like to have a committee meeting and review this
proof and this information in a legislative committee.
type of established level of recognition of that information.
And then, you know, have some
I'm not going to have a circus.
know and I know that for me to establish some type of an official report to the legislature
that I should call the legislature into session.
And to call them into a special session, I need two-thirds of the members to do
that, and I only have half plus one.
Arizona and the legislature, et cetera.
The Democrats aren't going to call me into session or
I'm not familiar with all of the laws of
You know, people can go out and do an ad hoc committee --1
mean, and not named by the President, but the speaker or the President, they can go get
a group of people together and talk about it and do what they want.
something to happen in the House, I'm not going to allow that.
Unless I see myself what it is we're talking about.
So I want to cover a couple things that you mentioned there.
that, early part of your answer, you said that the President encouraged Mr. Giuliani to
give you the evidence that you were looking for, and he said he would.
Did Mr. Giuliani give you the evidence that you were asking for in that
Not then and not a week later, not 2 weeks later, not now.
The other thing I want to follow up on, I thought you said that there
were two components to the ask and one of them you've just described, which is that
there be an official committee meeting by a standing committee.
component of the ask by Mr. Giuliani?
And then he said in this flowing of the conversation said:
from someone -- and I remember the phrase "high up in Republican circles" in the
legislature who said that Arizona law allows for you to call for the dismissal of the Biden
electors and the replacement of those electors by a new slate of electors for President
Trump if there was sufficient cause.
And the flavor of the discussion was that the committee meeting would prove
sufficient cause to allow us then to move to number two, which would be the dismissal or
the questioning of the electors that had already been elected.
already been taken by the people, you know, 2 and a half weeks earlier.
Speaker Bowers, did Mr. Giuliani identify this high up person in
the Republican circles in the legislature?
I would very much like to know who that is.
So you were the leading Republican in the House as speaker, I assume?
And Ms. Fann was the leading Republican in the Senate?
And was she on this phone call with you on November 22nd?
Was it your understanding that Mr. Giuliani was talking about President
No, it was not my understanding.
They never intimated any more than what I've told you.
opinion for who had been pressing this very issue and pressing me to allow him to hold a
committee meeting to review it, and that was Mr. Finchem, my Federal relations
In my view, I know exactly who it was, but I couldn't -- that's just my personal
Speaker Bowers, in your view, was there any merit to the position that Mr.
Finchem, or whoever this person was, was pressing on Mr. Giuliani that the Arizona State
legislature could disregard Biden electors and install electors for Trump instead?
At the time -- in fact, when he said that, my response was:
I've never heard that one before.
You need to tell me more about that.
information and that there is a legal theory and there's some legal work.
Rudy, can you think of a time that's ever happened in the United
I personally am not an expert on Arizona law.
It was later that I received a treatise -- I may have received it earlier by email, but I never
read it, wherein Mr. Finchem presents it as part of -- and he told -- he personally told me
that that was part of his term paper that he did as part of the legal studies program that
he was entered in with the University of Arizona.
And it also later came to my attention that John Eastman had had some
information that was used by Mr. Finchem as a, you know, legal theory upon which to
base his paper and that he cited in his paper.
But I had not any other clue other than that initial, you know, claim by Mr.
And he -- he backed right up.
I mean, he didn't try to give me scripture and
against Article 11, section 1, clause 2, about the legislative powers.
And he would have been way off, because the claim is
But that was what he had said, and I just said:
Rudy, you're asking me to do
something that is beyond anything I have ever heard or contemplated as a constitutional
prerogative or choice that I might take.
State at risk or cast a bad reputation on my State or on my body unless I know a lot more
about it and that I have competent legal -- and not necessarily from this conversation.
legal counsel on this issue, and I have some good lawyers.
may have gone beyond what you want me to answer, Mr. Harris.
And I will do nothing, nothing that will put my
I'm not going to go willy-nilly off and take some kind of decision without good
And -- and, in fact, I will -- I
So, Mr. Giuliani, the second part of his ask -- the first part was that you convene a
special -- or you bring the committee back into session, an official committee.
And the second ask was that the State legislature consider disregarding the Biden
electors and install the electors for Trump instead.
And, on that second ask, you told him you never heard of such a thing, right?
I never heard of such an authority or thing ever.
And you shared your skepticism with Mr. Giuliani?
Well, you know, we're all kind of Republicans and
we need to be working together.
And I said -- I mean, that was, you know, those little snippets would be in the
conversation and I know when I'm being worked.
And I know he's trying to work me to a point.
I mean, I've only been at it for a while.
And I believe that one -- one point the
We're just asking you to investigate.
I will give you the number of my attorney right now.
I have seen people do that on their cell phones, but I'm not real
familiar with it, and, Mr. President, I can't even tweet on this thing and watch; it'll be me
telling my grandkids that me trying to do this, and I hung up on the President of the
And so I did, and that's exactly what I did.
You're a man of your word.
said, hey -- he was laughing, and he said:
Hey, the President, he's a great guy.
And I got right back to dead serious.
remember, Mr. Giuliani, you said you had proof, and I want it.
of all these things you say are real.
You know that really is funny.
And so then we went on.
And then Mr. Giuliani immediately called me back and
And is that how you sort of left things at the end of that
It kind of ended that way.
lawyer get in touch with you.
And I gave him the number, and that's how we left the phone.
And I think you've already said that you didn't get the proof that you had
requested and that he had promised?
I understand that, a week or so after that call -- yes?
You can expect his call, and I expect you to call him.
Nor did he ever call Mr. Pappas.
I just wanted a couple of followup questions, Speaker Bowers.
Just to clarify, did the President participate in the entirety of the phone call?
And did you hear him ever challenge or dispute what Mr. Giuliani
And you mentioned that in part of your -- part of your discussion
here with us today that one of the second ask that you described about replacing the
electors in Arizona, the Biden electors with Trump electors, that you now understand that
the source of this argument was in the United States Constitution.
Did that come up during the call at that time, or is that something that you've
It did not come up in the call; it was later.
So, at the time of this call in November 2020, all that Mr. Giuliani
was asserting to you was that someone from Arizona Republican circles had told him that
there was an Arizona law that would provide you an avenue to replace the electors.
And did the President make any comment about that assertion by Mr.
Mr. Speaker, once again, thank you for spending part of your Father's Day with us
I just wanted to follow up and make sure that weren't leaving anything out.
Can you tell us, as best you can recall, each of the times the President spoke up during the
conversation and what he had to say?
Generally, I even thought, is this like a good cop, bad cop thing,
Rudy, give him what he needs.
It was never -- and then one time he said, "We would just like you to investigate
this," which was, in my view, I understood that to check it out:
What did the President say to you when he first got on the line with
We'd like to ask you if
Mr. Speaker, I've heard a lot about you.
We -- we'd like to talk with you about something that we've been
He didn't go right to any point, but it was kind of a general introduction, some
niceties, and then he turned it over to Rudy.
And what was the rest of the pat on the back stuff?
That he had heard that I was doing a great job.
did -- we had met when he had come to campaign, and we -- you know, we met him
coming down from Air Force One and went to an event with him and he gave the, you
know, the call to the stage and that kind of stuff.
So we had met and it was more like, you know, we really appreciate Arizona.
a great State, great people, that kind of -- it was like campaign talk.
So, when you said that you campaigned for him in the 2020 election,
you actually campaigned with him at times?
And was that more than once or what was the nature -I only recall one campaign -- large campaign event where we went.
And then I walked for the campaign and passed out flyers and, you know, went door to
So you actually as the speaker of the House of
Representatives in Arizona, you went door to door precinct, walking for President Trump?
He and Ms. McSally, yes, that's correct.
So, on the phone call after the pleasantries and the pat on the back,
he basically turns it over to Rudy to make the requests?
And, you know, as Giuliani is asking you to call the legislature into
session so that he can present whatever evidence he has or suggesting to you that the
legislature can somehow decertify the Biden electors or appoint Trump electors, is the
President commenting on this along the way?
I don't ever remember him saying, like "that's right" or "yes"
or "well said," nothing like that, never.
So his interjections were mostly to, as you say, good cop/bad cop to
prompt Rudy to tell you exactly what he wants you to do?
That is -- that is my recollection, Mr. Schiff.
And, on the first ask, Rudy Giuliani wanted you to reconvene the
legislature so he could present you with what he claimed was evidence of these
allegations of fraud, but you weren't willing to do that without seeing some -- some
outcome to this committee, that we would have to be in session, and that I talked about
Representative, my recollection is that he wanted a committee
It was my view that if we're going to have some official
But the committee meeting, the hope was for that so that they could present all of
these cases, whatever it was that they had in an official capacity, establish an official
record for whatever use they felt that was necessary.
And if I understood correctly, you had two strong objections to that?
One was you wanted to see some evidence first?
And, second, in the absence of that evidence, it was going to be
impossible to convince enough of the legislature, the two-thirds needed to bring it back
I think -- I had not thought that, but I think that is true.
view -- see, they have to vote.
We can -- I can say we're going to
meet on X date and you'll vote whether you come in or not.
And we have only called, I believe, the legislature has called itself into session one
They have to vote to come
time, and that was like in 1981 or -3, and it was to override a veto of the Governor.
So I have no practical knowledge of the A, B, C, Ds of calling the legislature into
And that -- we would just rely on the established protocols, but I knew that I
had to have nine Democrats ascent to calling us into session.
We had been fighting this battle for over a year on the COVID issue where they
wanted me to call them into session, repel the Governor's autocratic rule, et cetera.
And this had been a subject of hundreds, thousands of emails over the last period of
COVID time when we were out of session, couldn't meet, you know, many of the
problems that the whole country was going through.
So that point was, again, presented to me that I was just going to call us into
session, and I wanted to clarify to him how that would have to happen.
And, Mr. Speaker, can you tell us, again, as best you recall exactly
what Giuliani -- what his second request was, that is, what he was arguing you could do to
either decertify the Biden electors, appoint Trump electors?
What did he believe you had the power to do?
What was he asking you to
The bridge between the first point and the second point was me
Where are we going with this?
I get the ask of the committee, but to what
Well, we understood that there's this thing where you would be
And we got into the second ask.
And that was exactly it, that I would decertify because of obvious fraud, you know,
And by "decertify" you mean, he was asking --
Decertify the electors' position and decertify the election and allow
for the certification of a new slate of electors to go to Washington to represent Arizona
So his second ask was for you to call the legislature and to decertify
the electors for Biden, recertify electors for Trump, and send those to Washington?
That's as I understood it, yes.
And your response to him was what?
He did kind of a pivot.
I'd never heard that one before, you know, as
Has that ever been done before?
You know, I'm not familiar with Arizona law.
You're asking me to do something that has never been done
before, that's supposedly constitutional, and I swore an oath to the Constitution of the
United States, and I also swore an oath to the constitution and laws of my State, and I'm
going to just willy-nilly do this?
Should I honor the United States?
I swore an oath to both.
The United States Constitution trumps -- trumps the State
I said, I was -- I'll admit I was a little bit frustrated by now, and I said:
any such thing without sufficient proof, but also without sufficient -- I'm not going to do
this willy-nilly and make some commitment on the phone.
I have very good lawyers, and I will discuss this with them before I took any such
You mentioned earlier and you had the article and the verse was
Article II you mentioned, were you referring to -- which constitution when you were
The national -- I understand -- again, I'm no lawyer, but it was the
I didn't know if you had a similar article in Arizona.
It is not in such a position.
would have would not be in that position, and I'm looking at Mr. Pappas, and he's -- I can
see he's in agreement with me at least on one thing in my life.
During that part of the conversation where you were talking about
your oath of office, was it in that context that Mr. Giuliani brought up the fact that you're
both Republicans, that he was working you?
He never said he was working me.
No, I know, but you said he was working you.
He would say -- he would say -- and he used this later in another
meeting, and I don't want to conflate the two meetings, but he would say, "You know,
this is -- this is kind of a hostile reception, we're both Republicans, we're just talking about
this kind of thing," which was just kind of to soften my -- to try to soften me down
because I admit I was getting exercised.
But, in that first conversation in which the President is on the line, did
Giuliani also then remind you that you're both Republicans?
And, when you said before when you were asked this question by my
colleague, that he was working you and you --
You were mentioning you had been at this a long time, and you know
What did you mean by that?
That he was trying to convince me to do something, he was trying
to get me to make some commitment to move in his direction.
By appealing to your common party?
I think there was some appeal to the party, yes.
others a week or so later, he definitely said that more than once, you know:
I know specifically when we met with him and Jenna Ellis and
We're all friends here blah, blah, blah.
I will turn it back to my colleagues.
So, Speaker Bowers, about a week after that call, Mr. Giuliani appeared with
others, I believe Ms. Ellis and others, at, I guess, we've called them hotel hearings.
There was something in a hotel ballroom in Phoenix.
And that was on the same day that the Governor of Arizona Doug Ducey
certified Biden as the winner of the Presidential election in Arizona.
Did you attend this, I'll call it a hearing, but this gathering, this proceeding?
I didn't want any part of.
We had it playing in one of the staff -- on one of the staff
televisions, and I heard snippets, but I had other things that I was working on and
Man, you should've heard that one, you know, things
At one time, I walked through and saw them talking, and I believe -- I believe it
was Mr. Giuliani at the time saying something, but I have no recollection of any specific
The following day after that meeting -Can I just ask one clarifying question?
Speaker Bowers, the meeting, the legislative committee meeting, that Mr.
Giuliani asked you to convene during that first call with President Trump and Mr. Giuliani,
is this gathering at the hotel, did that qualify as an official committee meeting of the
Because there was senators, representatives, and I think there was even
couple of nonelecteds that were in the room and participating.
just a gathering of people, you know.
the hotel, but I do remember there was some -- a couple of senators, Peterson was a
senator-elect and Townsend was a senator-elect, Finchem was there.
Mr. Cook was there, I believe.
I don't have a breakdown of everybody who was on that committee there at
It was a weird -- it was
Mrs. Griffin, I believe, was there.
Both in the room and at the dais.
So it's fair to say that Mr. Giuliani did not get his
first ask that he raised on that phone call with you of official committee meeting, but
rather just participated in this unofficial gathering at the hotel ballroom?
He did participate in that gathering, but that is not -- I don't know
I never asked him whether he thought it was official, but it certainly
So, after the day after that gathering at the hotel, did you meet with Mr.
Were you expecting at that meeting that Mr. Giuliani would provide you
with the evidence of fraud that he had promised in your phone call on the 22nd?
Did Mr. Giuliani or anyone on his team provide the evidence that you had
And what did he say in response?
He turned, I believe, to his right, and I believe Jenna Ellis was to his right.
And I'm looking at you, Mr. Pappas.
At some time -- I don't know if you want to talk about that meeting, but
So Mr. Giuliani had promised you in a November 22nd call that he would get you
We don't have it with us.
Let me stop you on that for one second to make sure I understand.
proof of these claims of election fraud, right?
And the President actually said to him:
That's correct, on more than one occasion.
